awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Models, Metrics and Control Strategies for Energy Efficient Data Centers
awd_abstract_narration:
Project Title: 
GOALI: Models, Metrics, and Control Strategies for Energy Efficient Data Centers

PIs: Bruno Sinopoli and Bruce H. Krogh


Objective:  This project aims to improve the energy efficiency of data centers significantly by introducing coordinated control of the cooling systems and the information technology.  This requires new integrated, control-oriented models of data center dynamics representing thermal interactions between the computational system and the cooling system as a function of the control inputs to each system.  New metrics will also be developed to capture effectively the impact of control decisions on computational performance in the context of service level agreements (SLAs) and other objectives and constraints that arise in practice.  Multi-level, distributed control strategies will be developed to deal with the wide range of time-scales and spatial distributions that characterize data center dynamics.
Intellectual Merit:  This transformative research will lead to the first data center control strategies that explicitly coordinate cooling system actions with workload and power state allocations to achieve effective tradeoffs between computational performance and energy consumption.  These strategies will also leverage new degrees of freedom by relaxing performance requirements as allowed by SLAs. The control hierarchy is based on abstractions that reflect the range of spatial and temporal scales common in many large-scale cyber-physical systems.    
Broader Impact: The academic-industry collaboration in this GOALI project assures the results will be implementable in future data centers.  This will lead to significant reductions in the energy required to meet the demands for computation and storage in the U.S. for years to come.  Through courses and internships, engineering students will be introduced emerging concepts in cyber-physical systems research.

por.por_cntn:
Data center energy management depends critically upon the management of both computational resources and cooling resources. The innovations in our approach build on the coupled dynamic network model. The data center is conceived as the coupling of two networks: a physical network describing the thermal dynamics of servers and Computer Room Air Conditioning (CRAC) units and a computational network. The coupling among the two networks is due to the fact the servers generate heat when they are switched on and performing computations. Our control strategy takes this coupling into account and it coordinates the management of both the computational and physical resources based on the coupled network model. In simulation studies, we compared the performance of our control strategy (Coordinated) with two other operating strategies used in today's data centers: a strategy in which jobs are distributed uniformly across the available servers with constant, equal set point temperatures (Uniform strategy); and a strategy in which the jobs are allocated so as to minimize server power consumption and the CRAC units are operated in order to minimize cooling cost while maintaining acceptable temperatures given the thermal demands from the servers as determined through temperature measurements (Uncoordinated strategy).

We developed a two-level hierarchical distributed control strategy based on our coupled dynamics model. Two hierarchy levels were considered: the higher level controller generated the optimal set-points for the lower level controllers; lower level controllers then, generated actual control actions for their local sub-system. A linear cost function was considered at both levels as an approximation of a global, i.e. system-wide, cost function.

Our proposed coordinated strategy outperforms both the uncoordinated and the uniform strategies because it can leverage points in the operating space that are not explored by the uncoordinated strategy by accounting directly for the thermal implications of decisions in the allocation of jobs. Furthermore efficiency improvement are more pronounced when the data center is in a mid-utilization state. Negligible gains are obtained when the data center is either lightly (small load with a few servers on) or heavily (all servers on and computing) utilized. This observation further strenghtens the relevance of our approach as data centers are often operating at medium utlilization.  

Our results suggest that a hierarchical/distributed control approach can be effectively applied in controlling data centers even though the model considered to synthesize the control law is unable to predict with great accuracy future values of data center variables (e.g., large value of the perturbation parameter). The robustness of the control strategies is due to the fast feedback loop enforced by the low-level controllers and by exploiting the modularity of data center layout in the higher-level optimization.

Our experiments show that the gains in energy efficiency of the proposed coordinated control may heavily depend upon the layout of the data center and the heterogeneity and placement of the servers.
